ontologyMetadata.name: Microsoft Cloud Security Benchmark Ontology

creator.name: BAIV Platform - Ontology Architect Agent v4.0.0

ontologyMetadata.description: Comprehensive ontology for Microsoft Cloud Security Benchmark v2 (Preview) providing semantic understanding for cloud security governance, AI security controls, and multi-framework compliance mapping.
ontologyMetadata.purpose: Enable AI agents to provide semantic reasoning about cloud security controls including AI-specific controls, facilitate compliance assessments across 6 frameworks, generate implementation guidance, and support security governance.

v2Domains.description: Network Security covers controls to secure and protect networks, including securing virtual networks, establishing private connections, preventing and mitigating external attacks, and securing DNS.
Identity Management covers controls to establish a secure identity and access controls using identity and access management systems.
Privileged Access covers controls to protect privileged access to your tenant and resources.
Data Protection covers control of data protection at rest, in transit, and via authorized access mechanisms.
Asset Management covers controls to ensure security visibility and governance over your resources.
Logging and Threat Detection covers controls for detecting threats on cloud, and enabling, collecting, and storing audit logs for cloud services.
Incident Response covers controls in incident response life cycle - preparation, detection and analysis, containment, and post-incident activities.
Posture and Vulnerability Management focuses on controls for assessing and improving cloud security posture.
Endpoint Security covers controls in endpoint detection and response, including EDR and anti-malware.
Backup and Recovery covers controls to ensure that data and configuration backups are performed, validated, and protected.
DevOps Security covers the controls related to security engineering and operations in the DevOps processes.
Governance and Strategy covers establishing security governance through defining roles, responsibilities, and organizational commitment.

Artificial Intelligence Security covers controls to ensure the secure development, deployment, and operation of AI models and services, including AI platform security, AI application security and AI security monitoring.

aiSecurityControls.securityPrinciple: Only deploy AI models that have been formally approved through a trusted verification process, ensuring they meet security, compliance, and operational requirements before production use.
aiSecurityControls.riskToMitigate: AI model deployment without rigorous verification exposes organizations to supply chain attacks, malicious model behaviors, and compliance violations. Unverified models may contain backdoors, poisoned training data, or vulnerabilities.

mitreAtlasMappings.description: Adversaries embed backdoors in AI models to trigger malicious behavior
Adversaries upload poisoned models to marketplaces

implementationGuidance.title: Deploy centralized model registry
implementationGuidance.description: Establish a single source of truth for tracking model origin, verification status, and approval history
steps: Set up Azure Machine Learning model registry
Configure metadata tracking for model provenance
Enable security scanning results storage
Implement deployment authorization workflows

implementationExample.challenge: Enterprise needs to prevent deployment of unapproved or potentially compromised AI models from untrusted sources
implementationExample.solution: Identify approved model asset IDs, configure Azure Policy to deny unauthorized deployments, implement RBAC via Microsoft Entra ID
implementationExample.outcome: Only verified, approved AI models can be deployed to production, preventing supply chain attacks

aiSecurityControls.securityPrinciple: Implement comprehensive content validation and filtering across all stages of AI interaction—including input prompts, internal processing, and model outputs—to detect and block malicious content.
aiSecurityControls.riskToMitigate: Without comprehensive filtering, organizations remain vulnerable to prompt injection attacks, harmful content, and data poisoning that bypass single-layer defenses.

mitreAtlasMappings.description: Crafting malicious prompts to produce harmful outputs
Bypassing LLM security controls with crafted prompts
Introducing malicious data to compromise model integrity

implementationGuidance.title: Implement multi-layered content filtering
implementationGuidance.description: Establish comprehensive content filtering framework spanning input, processing, and output stages
steps: Deploy Azure AI Content Safety for input filtering
Configure input sanitization in data preprocessing pipelines
Use API gateway controls for rate-limiting and schema validation
Apply output filtering to block harmful responses
Log and audit all inputs/outputs in centralized system

implementationExample.challenge: Enterprise deploying AI chatbot needs to prevent prompt injection attacks and block harmful content
implementationExample.solution: Deploy Azure AI Content Safety as prompt shield, configure AML pipelines for input sanitization, enable Defender for Cloud runtime scanning
implementationExample.outcome: Chatbot successfully blocks prompt injection attempts and harmful content at multiple stages

aiSecurityControls.securityPrinciple: Use safety meta-prompts or system instructions to guide AI models toward intended, secure, and ethical behavior while enhancing resistance to prompt injection attacks.
aiSecurityControls.riskToMitigate: Without predefined system-level instructions, organizations face increased vulnerability to jailbreaking, prompt injection, and generation of harmful outputs.

mitreAtlasMappings.description: Adversaries manipulate LLM by crafting malicious prompts that override system prompts
Adversaries craft inputs to bypass safety protocols
Adversaries use prompt injection to trick model into executing unauthorized actions

implementationGuidance.title: Adopt safety meta-prompts
implementationGuidance.description: Establish safety meta-prompts creating foundational defense against prompt-based attacks
steps: Design explicit role definitions in meta-prompts
Embed prompts in system context during inference
Validate prompt effectiveness using NLP tools
Configure prompt prioritization over user inputs
Implement input validation layers for injection patterns
Conduct adversarial testing using PYRIT
Use spotlighting techniques to isolate untrusted data
Deploy logging and monitoring for triggered meta-prompts
Maintain version control for meta-prompt iterations

implementationExample.challenge: Software company deploying AI coding assistant needs to prevent generation of insecure code and reject adversarial prompts
implementationExample.solution: Craft safety meta-prompt restricting to secure code generation, integrate Azure AI Content Safety, test with PYRIT against adversarial prompts
implementationExample.outcome: AI coding assistant provides secure code while rejecting adversarial or malicious prompts

aiSecurityControls.controlName: Apply Least Privilege for Agent Functions
aiSecurityControls.securityPrinciple: Restrict the capabilities and access permissions of agent functions or plugins to the minimum required for their intended purpose.
aiSecurityControls.riskToMitigate: Without least-privilege enforcement, compromised or malicious functions can escalate privileges, access sensitive data, or enable lateral movement across systems.

mitreAtlasMappings.description: Exploiting compromised or overly privileged AI agent accounts
Using excessive AI agent privileges to navigate across systems
Extracting sensitive data via overly privileged AI agent functions

implementationGuidance.title: Apply least privilege for agent functions
implementationGuidance.description: Establish least-privilege framework for agent functions and plugins
steps: Define capability manifest for each agent function
Use sandboxed execution environment for isolation
Implement runtime policy enforcement
Leverage Microsoft Entra Agent ID for access control
Apply RBAC/ABAC based on function purpose
Use short-lived, scoped tokens for access
Enforce network segmentation
Deploy logging and monitoring for all activities
Configure anomaly detection for deviations
Establish review process before integration

implementationExample.challenge: Technology company deploying AI agent needs to restrict to read-only access on specific knowledge base
implementationExample.solution: Define capability manifest in Azure API Management, implement RBAC in Microsoft Entra ID, use Azure Key Vault for scoped tokens, apply network segmentation
implementationExample.outcome: Least-privilege framework restricts agent to specific actions, mitigating privilege escalation risks

aiSecurityControls.securityPrinciple: Implement human review and approval for critical actions or decisions taken by the AI application, especially when interacting with external systems or sensitive data.
aiSecurityControls.riskToMitigate: AI systems processing sensitive data or controlling external systems require human checkpoints to detect errors, adversarial manipulation, or unintended behaviors.

mitreAtlasMappings.description: Human approval prevents unauthorized data outflows
Human-in-the-loop mitigates harmful outcomes by validating decisions

implementationGuidance.title: Ensure human-in-the-loop
implementationGuidance.description: Implement HITL controls establishing critical checkpoints for high-risk AI operations
steps: Define critical actions requiring human review
Establish approval mechanisms using Azure Logic Apps
Train reviewers on AI behavior and vulnerabilities
Optimize review processes for efficiency
Incorporate feedback loops for model refinement
Secure HITL interfaces with encryption
Conduct regular testing of HITL robustness

implementationExample.challenge: Manufacturing company needs supervisors to verify critical system change requests from AI voice assistant
implementationExample.solution: Configure Azure AI Speech to flag critical commands, route through Azure Logic Apps to supervisor dashboard, log all interactions
implementationExample.outcome: Human verification safeguards critical manufacturing operations, ensuring safety protocol compliance

aiSecurityControls.securityPrinciple: Implement robust monitoring solutions to detect suspicious activity, investigate risks, identify jailbreak attempts, and correlate findings with threat intelligence.
aiSecurityControls.riskToMitigate: Without AI-specific monitoring, attackers exploit prompt interfaces, manipulate models, or exfiltrate data through AI interactions while remaining undetected.

mitreAtlasMappings.description: Identifying compromised credentials or unauthorized API calls
Identifying unauthorized data transfers from AI systems

implementationGuidance.title: Establish monitoring and detection
implementationGuidance.description: Deploy comprehensive AI-specific monitoring and detection capabilities
steps: Implement Microsoft Defender for AI Services
Enable real-time behavioral monitoring
Deploy Microsoft Purview for data security monitoring
Integrate threat intelligence feeds (MITRE ATLAS, OWASP)
Implement anomaly detection using Azure AI Anomaly Detector
Centralize logging and analysis in Azure Log Analytics
Automate alerting and escalation with Azure Monitor
Conduct regular testing and validation
Ensure compliance and auditability

implementationExample.challenge: Global logistics company needs to detect AI-specific threats to route optimization system
implementationExample.solution: Deploy Microsoft Defender for AI Services, integrate Azure Sentinel with MITRE ATLAS, use Microsoft Purview for data classification, deploy Azure AI Anomaly Detector
implementationExample.outcome: Real-time detection of AI-specific threats while protecting operational data from unauthorized access

aiSecurityControls.securityPrinciple: Proactively test AI systems using adversarial techniques to discover vulnerabilities, adversarial paths, and potential harmful outcomes.
aiSecurityControls.riskToMitigate: Without systematic adversarial testing, organizations deploy AI systems with unknown weaknesses that attackers can exploit through prompt injection, model poisoning, or jailbreaking.

mitreAtlasMappings.description: Simulating prompt injection or jailbreaking to gain unauthorized access
Simulating data leakage through inference attacks

implementationGuidance.title: Perform continuous AI red teaming
implementationGuidance.description: Integrate adversarial testing into AI development and deployment lifecycle
steps: Define red teaming objectives aligned with business requirements
Leverage PYRIT for automated adversarial testing
Deploy Azure AI Red Teaming Agent for targeted tests
Integrate open-source frameworks (Adversarial Robustness Toolbox)
Simulate real-world scenarios based on MITRE ATLAS
Integrate red teaming in CI/CD pipelines
Involve cross-functional teams in exercises
Monitor and analyze red teaming results
Maintain comprehensive audit trails
Iterate and remediate vulnerabilities
Adopt continuous testing cadence (monthly/quarterly)

implementationExample.challenge: E-commerce platform needs to continuously identify vulnerabilities in AI product recommendation chatbot
implementationExample.solution: Set up Azure AI Red Teaming Agent for prompt injection and jailbreak simulation, integrate PYRIT in CI/CD pipeline, log outcomes in Azure Monitor
implementationExample.outcome: Continuous red teaming identifies and mitigates risks before deployment, ensuring secure operation

controls.controlName: Use strong authentication controls for all Azure Active Directory based access
controls.securityPrinciple: Use strong authentication methods for all Azure AD-based access including MFA and passwordless authentication.
controls.azureGuidance: Configure Azure AD MFA, enable passwordless authentication, implement conditional access policies.
controls.note: v2 adds NIST CSF v2.0, ISO 27001:2022, SOC 2 mappings and enhanced implementation examples

controls.securityPrinciple: Ensure internal network traffic is secured using virtual networks, network security groups, and service endpoints.
controls.azureGuidance: Deploy Azure Virtual Networks, configure NSGs, enable private endpoints for Azure services.
controls.note: v2 adds risk-to-mitigate, MITRE ATT&CK mappings, implementation examples

controls.securityPrinciple: Protect sensitive data at rest using encryption with platform-managed or customer-managed keys.
controls.azureGuidance: Enable Azure Storage Service Encryption, configure Azure Disk Encryption, use Azure Key Vault for key management.
controls.note: v2 adds AI model artifact encryption guidance
